Let $$

directions, respectively.

Then, the traction components $$

T_{i}(\mathbf{n})$$

acting on a surface with normal n are given by}

$$

T_{i}(\mathbf{n}) = T_{i}(\mathbf{e}_{1})n_{1} + T_{i}(\mathbf{e}_{2})n_{2} + T_{i}(\mathbf{e}_{3})n_{3}$$

The base and sides of the tetrahedron have normals in the $$

directions.

The fourth face has normal n.

Suppose the volume of the tetrahedron is dV, and let $$

dA_{1}$$

,  $$

dA_{2}$$

,  $$

dA_{3}$$

,  $$

dA_{n}$$

denote the areas of the faces.

Assume that the material within the tetrahedron has mass density $$

\rho$$

and is subjected to a body force b.

Let a denote the acceleration of the center of mass of the tetrahedron.

Then, F\emph{=}ma for the tetrahedron requires that}

$$

\mathbf{T}(\mathbf{n})dA^{(n)} + \mathbf{T}( - \mathbf{e}_{1})dA_{1} + \mathbf{T}( - \mathbf{e}_{2})dA_{2} + \mathbf{T}( - \mathbf{e}_{3})dA_{3} + \rho\mathbf{b}dV = \rho dV\mathbf{a}$$

{Recall that $$

\mathbf{T}( - \mathbf{e}_{i}) = - \mathbf{T}(\mathbf{e}_{i})$$

and divide through by $$

dA_{n}$$

:}

$$

\mathbf{T}(\mathbf{n}) - \mathbf{T}(\mathbf{e}_{1})\frac{dA_{1}}{dA^{(n)}} - \mathbf{T}(\mathbf{e}_{2})\frac{dA_{2}}{dA^{(n)}} - \mathbf{T}(\mathbf{e}_{3})\frac{dA_{3}}{dA^{(n)}} + \rho\mathbf{b}\frac{dV}{dA^{(n)}} = \rho\frac{dV}{dA^{(n)}}\mathbf{a}$$

\left. dA_{n}\rightarrow 0 \right.$$

.  We can show (see Appendix D) that}

by}}

$$

{The material stress tensor can also be visualized as force per unit undeformed area, except that the forces are regarded as acting within the undeformed solid, rather than on the deformed solid.

Specifically}

{1.{      }}{The infinitesimal force }$$

d\mathbf{P}^{(\mathbf{n})}$$

{ }is assumed to behave like an infinitesimal material fiber in the solid, in the sense that it is stretched and rotated just like an small vector dx in the solid{}

{2.{      }}{This means that we can define a (fictitious) force in the reference configuration $$

d\mathbf{P}^{(\mathbf{n}0)}$$

that is related to $$

d\mathbf{P}^{(\mathbf{n})}$$

by $$

\mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{P}^{(\mathbf{n}0)} = d\mathbf{P}^{(\mathbf{n})}$$

or $$

F_{ij}dP_{j}{}^{(\mathbf{n}0)} = dP_{i}{}^{(\mathbf{n})}$$

.}

{3.{      }}{This fictitious force is related to material stress by $$

dP_{i}^{(\mathbf{n}0)} = dA_{0}n_{j}^{0}\Sigma_{ji}$$

}

{ }

{To see this, substitute into the expression relating $$

d\mathbf{P}^{(n)}$$

to nominal stress to see that}

$$

F_{ik}dP_{k}^{(\mathbf{n}0)} = dA_{0}n_{j}^{0}S_{ji}$$

{Finally multiply through by $$

F_{li}^{- 1}$$

, note $$

F_{li}^{- 1}F_{ik} = \delta_{lk}$$

, and rearrange to see that}

$$

dP_{l}^{(\mathbf{n}0)} = dA_{0}n_{j}^{0}S_{ji}F_{li}^{- 1} = dA_{0}n_{j}^{0}\Sigma_{jl}$$

{where we have noted that $$

\Sigma_{jl} = S_{ji}F_{li}^{- 1}$$

}

{ }

{In practice, it is best not to try to attach too much physical significance to these stress measures.

Cauchy stress is the best physical measure of internal force $$

–$$

it is the force per unit area acting inside the deformed solid.

The other stress measures are best regarded as generalized forces (in the sense of Lagrangian mechanics), which are work-conjugate to particular strain measures.

This means that the stress measure multiplied by the time derivative of the strain measure tells you the rate of work done by the forces.

When setting up any mechanics problem, we always work with conjugate measures of motion and forces.}

{ }

{Specifically, we shall show later that the rate of work $$

\overset{˙}{W}$$

done by stresses acting on a small material element with volume $$

dV_{0}$$

in the undeformed solid (and volume $$

dV$$

in the deformed solid) can be computed as }

$$

\overset{˙}{W} = D_{ij}\sigma_{ij}dV = D_{ij}\tau_{ji}dV_{0} = {\overset{˙}{F}}_{ij}S_{ji}dV_{0} = {\overset{˙}{E}}_{ij}\Sigma_{ji}dV_{0}$$

{where $$

D_{ij}$$

is the stretch rate tensor, $$

{\overset{˙}{F}}_{ij}$$

is the rate of change of deformation gradient, and $$

{\overset{˙}{E}}_{ij}$$

is the rate of change of Lagrange strain tensor.

Note that Cauchy stress (and also Kirchhoff stress) is not conjugate to any convenient strain measure $$

–$$

A vector is an object which has magnitude and direction.

Example include forces, electric fields, normal to a surface, etc.

A vector is represented as $\bm a$, and scalars are represented with lowercase greek letters.

Usually, lowercase letters are used to denote vectors.

Its magnitude is denoted as $\vert \bm a \vert$. Special cases of vectors are: \begin{itemize} \item The unit vector $\bm n$ has $\vert \bm a \vert = 1$, \item The null vector $\bm 0$ has $\vert \bm 0 \vert = 0$, \end{itemize}

We now define operations between vectors.

Addition: $\bm a + \bm b =  \bm c$

Multiplication by scalar: $\alpha \bm a  =  \bm b$ and $\vert \alpha \bm a  \vert  =  \vert \bm b \vert $

Dot product or scalar product: $  \alpha =  \bm a \cdot \bm b $, is defined as $\alpha  = \bm a \cdot \bm b  = \vert  \bm a  \vert \vert  \bm b  \vert \cos \theta(\bm a, \bm b) $

Cross product or vector product: $ \bm c = \bm a \times \bm b $, is defined as $\vert  \bm c \vert  = \bm a \times \bm b  = \vert  \bm a  \vert \vert  \bm b  \vert \sin \theta(\bm a, \bm b) $

\begin{tcolorbox}[colback=black!5!white,colframe=black!75!black,title=Exercises] Show the following statements: \begin{itemize} \item Show that a unit vector can always be constructed for a given vector $\bm a$. \item Shows that if two vectors do not have magnitude zero and their dot product is $\bm a \cdot \bm b = 0$, then they are perpendicular. \item Show that $\bm a \times \bm b = - \bm b \times \bm a$ and $\bm a \cdot (\bm a \times \bm b) = \bm b \cdot (\bm a \times \bm b) = \bm 0 $. \end{itemize} \end{tcolorbox}

Let $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$ be three mutually perpendicular unit vectors which form a right handed triad.

Then, $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$ are said to form an orthonormal basis.

The vectors satisfy

\begin{equation} \vert  \bm e_1 \vert = \vert  \bm e_2 \vert = \vert  \bm e_3 \vert =1,      \bm e_1 \times \bm e_2 = \bm e_3,      \bm e_1 \times \bm e_3 = \bm -e_2,      \bm e_2 \times \bm e_3 = \bm e_1. \end{equation}

Now, any vector $\bm a$ can be expressed using a suitable combination of the unit vectors $\bm e_1$, $ \bm e_2$, and $ \bm e_3$. For example, we may write

\begin{equation} \bm a = \alpha_1 \bm e_1 +  \alpha_2 \bm e_2 +  \alpha_3 \bm e_3 = \sum_{i=1}^3 \alpha_i \bm e_i \end{equation} % where $(\alpha_1, \alpha_2, \alpha_3)$ are scalars called the components of $\bm a$ in the basis $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$. The components of $\bm a$ have a simple physical interpretation, i.e,

\begin{equation} \bm a \cdot \bm e_1 = (\alpha_1 \bm e_1 +  \alpha_2 \bm e_2 +  \alpha_3 \bm e_3)\cdot \bm e_1 = \alpha_1. \end{equation} are the projections of the vector over the axis $\bm e_i$.

Using the Cartesian components, we now can define the vector operations as

$\bm c = \bm a + \bm b  \Longleftrightarrow  c_1 = a_1 + b_1;   c_2 = a_2 + b_2;   c_3 = a_3 + b_3$,

$ \bm a \cdot \bm b  = \sum_{i=1}^3 a_i b_i$,

$\bm c = \bm a \times \bm b  \Longleftrightarrow  c_1 = a_2 b_3 - a_3 b_2;   c_2 = a_3 b_1 - a_1 b_3;   c_3 = a_1 b_2 - a_2 b_1$.

Let $\bm a$ be a vector, and let $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$  be a Cartesian basis.

Suppose that the components of $\bm a$ in the basis $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$  are known to be ($a_1,  a_2,  a_3$).

Now, suppose that we wish to compute the components of $\bm a$ in a second Cartesian basis, $\{ \bm m_1, \bm m_2, \bm m_3 \}$. This means that we wish to find components $(\alpha_1, \alpha_2, \alpha_3)$, such that

\begin{equation} \bm a = \alpha_1 \bm m_1 + \alpha_2 \bm m_2 + \alpha_3 \bm m_3 \end{equation}

To do so, we note that

\begin{equation} \bm Q = \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & \sin \theta \\ -\sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ \end{pmatrix} \end{equation} The proof follows trivially remembering that $\cos^2\theta+\sin^2\theta=1$.

\begin{itemize} \item Area between vectors $A = \frac{1}{2} \vert \bm a \times \bm b \vert $ \item Angle between vectors $\theta = \cos^{-1} \big(\frac{\bm a \cdot \bm b}{\vert \bm a \vert \vert \bm b \vert} \big) $ \item Normal to two vectors $\bm n = \pm \frac{\bm a \times \bm b}{\vert \bm a \times \bm b \vert}$ \item Volume enclosed by three vectors $V = \vert \bm c \cdot (\bm a \times \bm b) \vert$ \end{itemize}

Exercise 1: Let $\bm r = \bm r(s,t)$ describe a parametric equation, where $s$ and $t$ are two parameters and $\bm r$ is the position vector of a point on the surface.

How would you compute the normal to the surface?

Exercise 2:  How can you compute the area in the parallelepiped defined by these three vectors?

\newpage \subsection{Tensor notation and multiplication using index notation}

Index notation is a compact way of writing systems of equations.

It can be used as a replacement for long hand-writing of equations or matrix representation.

A matrix is more valuable for representing the storage of values in the system, but for writing equations in a compact form, and especially for higher order tensors, index notation is superior.

Unless otherwise stated, all indices go between 1 and 3.

Boldface type lowercase letters (i.e., $\bm a$) are vectors and boldface uppercase letters (i.e., $\bm Q$) are matrices.

Let us start with the simple representation of a vector in index notation:

\begin{equation} {\bm a} = a_i,      i = 1,\ldots,3. \end{equation}

The three entries in the vector $\bm a$ are represented by $a_1, a_2, a_3$. The index letter is incremented from its starting value (1) to its ending value (3).

Let us examine the vector dot product, which has a scalar result.

Here we learn a new feature of index notation: sum over repeated indices.

\begin{equation} \bm a \cdot \bm b  = [a_1 a_2  a_3] \begin{pmatrix}   b_1 \\ b_2 \\b_3 \end{pmatrix} = a_1b_1 + a_2 b_2 + a_3 b_3 = c \end{equation}

\begin{equation} a_i b_i  = a_1b_1 + a_2 b_2 + a_3 b_3 = c \end{equation}

It is easily seen that as the index $i$ is incremented, the multiplication takes place and the result is added together.

For $i = 1$, we multiply $a_1$ and $b_1$, then $i$ is incremented and we multiply $a_2$ and $b_2$, then $i$ is incremented and so on.

The repeated index $i$ indicates that the results of the three multiplications should be added. \\

\begin{tcolorbox}[colback=black!5!white,colframe=black!75!black,title=Important remark] There are two important things that are shown by the index notation in equation  ($a_ib_i$), but not by the vector notation in equation  ($\bm a \cdot \bm b$). \begin{itemize} \item The first is that the repeated index in $a_i$ and $b_i$ shows that the dimensions of $\bm a$ and $\bm b$ must be the same.

The vector notation does not show this, even though one should know that this needs to be the case for this simple example.

This becomes more useful in higher order tensors. \item The second piece of information is the fact that the final result will be a 0$^{\text{th}}$ order tensor, or scalar.

Anytime there are repeated indices in a tensor multiplication, this degree of the tensor will be canceled out.

Let $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$  be a Cartesian basis with origin O in three dimensional space.

Let

\begin{equation} \bm r  = x_1 \bm e_1 + x_2 \bm e_2 + x_3 \bm e_3 \end{equation} % denote the position vector of a point in space.

A scalar field is a scalar valued function of position in space.

A scalar field is a function of the components of the position vector, and so many expressed as $\phi(x_1,x_2,x_3)$. The value $\phi$ at a particular point in space must be independent of the choice of basis vectors.

A scalar field may be a function of time (and possibly other parameters) as well as position in space.

Can you think on some examples of scalar fields?

Let $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$  be a Cartesian basis with origin O in three dimensional space.

Let

\begin{equation} \bm r  = x_1 \bm e_1 + x_2 \bm e_2 + x_3 \bm e_3 \end{equation} % denote the position vector of a point in space.

A vector field is a vector valued function of position in space.

A vector field is a function of the components of the position vector, and so may be expressed as $\bm v (x_1,x_2,x_3)$. The vector may also be expressed as components in the basis $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$

\begin{equation} \bm v (x_1,x_2,x_3)  = v_1(x_1,x_2,x_3) \bm e_1 + v_2(x_1,x_2,x_3) \bm e_2 + v_3(x_1,x_2,x_3) \bm e_3. \end{equation} % The magnitude and direction of $\bm v$ at a particular point in space is independent of the choice of basis vectors.

A vector field may be a function of time (and possibly other parameters) as well as position in space.

Let $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$  be a Cartesian basis with origin O in three dimensional space.

Express the position vector of a point relative to O in  $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$  as \begin{equation} \bm r  = x_1 \bm e_1 + x_2 \bm e_2 + x_3 \bm e_3, \end{equation} % and let $\phi(x_1,x_2,x_3)$ be a scalar field.

Let $\{ \bm m_1, \bm m_2, \bm m_3 \}$ be a second Cartesian basis, with origin P.

Let $\bm c = \overrightarrow{OP}$ denote the position vector of P relative to O.

Express the position vector of a point relative to P in $\{ \bm m_1, \bm m_2, \bm m_3 \}$ as \begin{equation} \bm p  = \xi_1 \bm m_1 + \xi_2 \bm m_2 + \xi_3 \bm m_3. \end{equation}

To find $\phi(x_1,x_2,x_3)$, use the following procedure.

First, express $\bm p$ as a components in the basis $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$, as explained in section ,

\begin{equation} \bm p  = p_1 \bm e_1 + p_2 \bm e_2 + p_3 \bm e_3. \end{equation} % where

\begin{equation} p_1 =   \xi_1 \bm e_1 \cdot \bm m_1 + \xi_2 \bm e_2 \cdot  \bm m_1 + \xi_3 \bm e_3 \cdot  \bm m_1 \end{equation} \begin{equation} p_2 =   \xi_2 \bm e_1 \cdot \bm m_2 + \xi_2 \bm e_2 \cdot  \bm m_2 + \xi_3 \bm e_3 \cdot  \bm m_1 \end{equation} \begin{equation} p_3 =   \xi_2 \bm e_1 \cdot \bm m_3 + \xi_2 \bm e_2 \cdot  \bm m_3 + \xi_3 \bm e_3 \cdot  \bm m_3 \end{equation} % or using index notation

\begin{equation} p_i = Q_{ij} \xi_j \end{equation} % where the transformation matrix $Q_{ij}$ is defined in Section . Now, express $\bm c$ as components in $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$, and note that

\begin{equation} \bm r = \bm p + \bm c, \end{equation} % such that \begin{equation} \phi(x_1,x_2,x_3) = \phi(p_1+c_1,p_2+c_2,p_2+c_3) =  \phi(Q_{1j}\xi_j + c_1, Q_{2j}\xi_j + c_2, Q_{3j}\xi_j + c_3 ). \end{equation}

Similar procedure can be follow to perform change of basis for vector fields.

This is leave to the student to show.

\begin{equation} \frac{d}{dt} \bigg[  \alpha(t) \bm a(t)  \bigg] = \dot{\alpha}(t) \bm a(t) + \alpha(t) \dot{\bm a}(t), \end{equation} \begin{equation} \frac{d}{dt} \bigg[  \bm a(t) \bm b(t)  \bigg] = \dot{\bm a}(t) \bm b(t) + \bm a(t) \dot{\bm b}(t), \end{equation} \begin{equation} \frac{d}{dt} \bigg[  \bm a(t) \times \bm b(t)  \bigg] = \dot{\bm a}(t) \times \bm b(t) + \bm a(t)  \times \dot{\bm b}(t), \end{equation}

It is often convenient to express position vectors as components in a basis which rotates with time.

To write equations of motion one must evaluate time derivatives of rotating vectors.

Let $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$ be a basis which rotates with instantaneous angular velocity $\bm \Omega$. Then,

\begin{equation} \frac{d \bm e_1}{dt} = \bm \Omega \times \bm e_1,    \frac{d \bm e_2}{dt} = \bm \Omega \times \bm e_2,    \frac{d \bm e_3}{dt} = \bm \Omega \times \bm e_3. \end{equation}

Let $\phi$ be a scalar field in three dimensional space.

The gradient of $\phi$ is a vector field denoted by $\bf grad(\phi)$ or $\phi \nabla$, and it is defined so that

\begin{equation} (\phi \nabla) \cdot a =  \lim_{\epsilon \to 0} \frac{\phi(\bm r + \epsilon \bm a) - \phi(\bm r)}{\epsilon}. \end{equation}

Let $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$ be a Cartesian basis with origin O in three dimensional space.

Let \begin{equation} \bm r  = x_1 \bm e_1 + x_2 \bm e_2 + x_3 \bm e_3, \end{equation} % denote the position vector of a point in space.

Express $\phi$ as a function of the components of $\bm r$. The gradient of $phi$ in this basis is then given by \begin{equation} \phi \nabla = \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x_1} \bm e_1 + \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x_2} \bm e_2 + \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x_3} \bm e_3, \end{equation}

\begin{equation} \phi \nabla_i =  \phi_{,i} = \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x_i}      i = 1,\ldots,3. \end{equation}

The two definitions are equivalent.

The comma in the index notation indicates to take the derivative of $\phi$ with respect to each coordinate $x_i$, which is the definition of a gradient.

Since there are no repeated indices, there is no summation.

Again, the number of unique indices still indicates what the order of the resulting tensor will be.
In this case, there is one unique index ($i$), therefore a 1$^{\text{st}}$ order tensor results, as is the case for gradients of scalar functions.

Let $\bm v$ be a vector field in three dimensional space.

The gradient of $\bm v$ is a tensor field denoted by ${\bf grad}(\bm v)$ or $\bm v \otimes \nabla$, and is defined so that \begin{equation} (\bm v \otimes \nabla) \cdot a =  \lim_{\epsilon \to 0} \frac{\bm v(\bm r + \epsilon \bm a) - \bm v  (\bm r)}{\epsilon}, \end{equation} % for every position $\bm r $ in space and for every vector $\bm a$. Let $\{ \bm e_1, \bm e_2, \bm e_3 \}$ be a Cartesian basis with origin O in three dimensional space.

Let \begin{equation} \bm r  = x_1 \bm e_1 + x_2 \bm e_2 + x_3 \bm e_3, \end{equation} denote the position vector of  a point in space.

Express $\bm v$ as a function of the components of $\bm r$, so that

\begin{equation} \bm v \otimes \nabla = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial v_1}{\partial x_1} &  \frac{\partial v_1}{\partial x_2}  & \frac{\partial v_1}{\partial x_3}  \\ \frac{\partial v_2}{\partial x_1} &  \frac{\partial v_2}{\partial x_2}  & \frac{\partial v_2}{\partial x_3}  \\ \frac{\partial v_3}{\partial x_1} &  \frac{\partial v_3}{\partial x_2}  & \frac{\partial v_3}{\partial x_3}   \end{pmatrix}. \end{equation}
Alternatively, in index notation \begin{equation} \big[ \bm v \otimes \nabla \big]_{ij} \equiv \frac{\partial v_i}{\partial x_j} \end{equation}

Let $V$ be a closed region in three dimensional space, bounded by an orientable surface $S$. Let $\bm n$ denote the unit vector normal to $S$, taken so that $\bm n$ points out of $V$. Let $\bm u$ be a vector field which is continuous and has continuous first partial derivatives in some domain containing T.

Then

\begin{equation} \int_V \text{div}(\bm u) dV = \int_S \bm u \cdot \bm n dA, \end{equation} alternatively, expressed in index notation \begin{equation} \int_V \frac{\partial u_i}{\partial x_i} dV = \int_S u_i n_i dA. \end{equation}

\newpage

Let us take another step and examine matrices, or 2$^{\text{nd}$ order tensors}:

\begin{equation} \bm A = \begin{pmatrix} A_{11}  & A_{12} & A_{13}\\ A_{21}  & A_{22} & A_{23}\\ A_{31}  & A_{32} & A_{33} \end{pmatrix} = A_{ij},      i=1,\ldots,3;   j = 1,\ldots,3. \end{equation}

There are now two unique indices ($i$ and $j$).

As noted previously, the number of unique indices indicates the order of the tensor, 2$^{\text{nd}}$ order, in this case.

\begin{tcolorbox}[colback=black!5!white,colframe=black!75!black,title=Important remark] The total number of entries in a tensor can be determined by multiplying the range of all unique indices.

Since $i = 1, \ldots, 3$, and $j = 1, \ldots, 3$ above, the total number of entries in the tensor is $3 \cdot 3 = 9$, this is confirmed by the $3 \times 3$ matrix above. \end{tcolorbox}

Let us examine scalar-matrix multiplication:

\begin{equation} c \bm A = \begin{pmatrix} cA_{11}  & cA_{12} & cA_{13}\\ cA_{21}  & cA_{22} & cA_{23}\\ cA_{31}  & cA_{32} & cA_{33} \end{pmatrix} = \bm B  = \begin{pmatrix} B_{11}  & B_{12} & B_{13}\\ B_{21}  & B_{22} & B_{23}\\ B_{31}  & B_{32} & B_{33} \end{pmatrix} . \end{equation} Or in index notation, \begin{equation} B_{ij} = c A_{ij}. \end{equation}

This case is simple, since the same scalar multiplies each entry in $A_{ij}$ as $i$ and $j$ are incremented.

There are not any repeated indices, therefore no summation.

Also, there is no reduction in the order of the tensor, as indicated by the fact that there are no repeated indices.

Finally, since the scalar does not have any indices, the bounds on $i$ and $j$ do not matter as far as compatible dimensions are concerned.

For the matrix-vector product, there are several things made apparent by the index notation:

\begin{equation} \bm d = \bm A  \cdot \bm b \end{equation}

\begin{equation} d_i = A_{ij} b_j \end{equation}

The repeated index ($j$) indicates that you should sum over the index $j$ (this is illustrated in detail below).

It also indicates that the the second dimension of the matrix must match that of the vector.

Finally, the repeated index will be canceled, leaving only the index $i$. One index indicates a 1$^{\text{st}}$ order tensor, or a vector, which is, of course, what happens when a matrix and vector are multiplied.

Let us carry out the multiplication in equation  in detail:

$i=2;  k=2; j=1,\ldots,3;\longrightarrow$ Keep $i$ fixed, increment $k$, and sum for all values of $j$ as it is incremented: \begin{equation} D_{22} = A_{21} B_{12} + A_{22} B_{22} + A_{23} B_{32} \end{equation}

It can be readily verified that the index procedure is the same as a standard matrix-vector multiplication.

Again, the repeated index is incremented while the unique indices are fixed.

The unique indices are also incremented.

Even though $k$ as incremented fully twice, and $i$ only once, the results would be the same if the procedure was reversed.

A useful identity is the following:

\begin{equation} \varepsilon_{ijk} \varepsilon_{ilm} = \delta_{jl} \delta_{km} - \delta_{jm} \delta_{kl} \end{equation}

The final step is to apply the equilibrium conditions.

The repeated index $j$ indicates that there will be a summation over $j$ and the the result of $ij$, will be a vector, since the index $j$ cancels out.

\begin{equation} \sigma_{ij,j} + b_i = 0, \end{equation} or \begin{equation} \frac{\partial \sigma_{ij}}{\partial x_j} + b_i = 0. \end{equation} % where $b_i$ are the body forces acting in the Cartesian directions.

The two above definitions are equivalent.

Let us look at the two equations that result by expanding these equations:

\begin{equation} \begin{cases} \frac{\partial \sigma_{11}}{\partial x_1} +\frac{\partial \sigma_{12}}{\partial x_2} + b_1 = 0 \\ \frac{\partial \sigma_{12}}{\partial x_1} +\frac{\partial \sigma_{22}}{\partial x_2} + b_2 = 0. \end{cases} \end{equation}

These strain and stress derivatives illustrate how taking derivatives can either increase or decrease the order of the tensor result. index notation makes it easy to keep track of the appropriate derivatives and also makes it clear what the final order of the tensor will be.

Notation: Bold face lowercase letters denote vectors, bold face uppercase letters denote second order tensors. \\

Problem 1: Expand explicitly the following expressions.

Write their equivalents in tensor notation. \begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)] \item $\nu_i u_i$ \item $\delta_{ii}$ \item $\nu_{i,i}$ \item $\delta_{ij,j}$ \item $\epsilon_{ijk} v_j u_k$ \item $\delta_{mi}\delta_{mj} T_{ij}$ \item $Q_{ij}T_{ik}Q_{km}$ \item $\epsilon_{ijk} \sigma_{jk}$ where $\sigma_{jk} = \sigma_{kj}$ \end{enumerate}

Problem 2: Write the following expressions in index notation.

Note: Since we have not defined second order operations, exercise 2(e)-(g) are optional.

\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)] \item $(\mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{v}) \cdot \mathbf{w}$ \item $\text{det }\mathbf{T}$ (hint: use 2a) \item $\nabla \times \mathbf{v}$ \item $\nabla \cdot \mathbf{v} $ \item $\nabla \times \mathbf{T}$ \item $\nabla \times (\nabla \mathbf{T})$ \item $\nabla \cdot \mathbf{T}$ \end{enumerate}

Problem 3: Using Problem 2, show that det $\mathbf{AB}$ = det$\mathbf{A}$ det$\mathbf{B}$.

Problem 4:  Show that $\epsilon_{pqr} \text{det} \mathbf{T} = \epsilon_{ijk} T_{ip} T_{jq} T_{kr}$ and then det$\mathbf{T} = \frac{1}{6} \epsilon_{ijk} \epsilon_{pqr} T_{ip} T_{jq} T_{kr}$.

Problem 5: Proof the following identities:

\begin{equation} \bm Q^{-1} = \bm Q^T,      \bm Q  \bm Q^T = \bm Q^T  \bm Q = \bm I. \end{equation} % where $\bm Q$ is a rotation matrix.

\newpage \section{Deformation gradient}

Let us now start considering the deformation of bodies.

Notice that this applies to any body, including fluids nad solids.

What we seek to develop is a series of tools that express the geometrical changes of bodies.

In particular, we try to describe how points, line segments, areas and volumes in the body are deformed.

We also do not want to use complex formulae using trigonometry or expressions involving trigonometric functions.

Thus, we will describe how body deform via a tool that is called the {\bf deformation gradient}, tradiationally denoted with a letter {\bf F} (yes, as you can guess, the deformation gradient {\bf F} is a {\bf second order tensor}.

\par But before we start talking about tensors, let us start with the basics, the displacement of points in bodies.

To this end, we first use a Cartesian triad, defined by three-mutually orthonormal and unit vectors $\{ \bf e_1, e_2, e_3 \}$. These vector are also known as orthogonal to denote that they are unit vectors and orthonormal to each other.

Then, we define the reference volume $\Omega_0$ of a body (traditionally, bodies in solids are draw as potato like shape).

With all these ingredients, let us now tag a point, $P$, which has a vector, let us say $\bf x$, in the reference configuration\footnote{notice that the reference configuration becomes an important concept in solids, since we are going to describe motion from this particular configuration.

The reference configuration is usuially denoted by  $\Omega_0$.}  $\bf x$ represents the vector measured from the point to the origin of the Cartesian triad.

\par Here is when things become more interesting.

Let us assume that there is an external estimulus (e.g., force, chemical reaction, electrostatic field) that produces a deformation (a change in shape and volume) of the body.

Initially, we will assume that the body just deforms, and we are going to ignore what causes of this deformation.

We now can guess what happens with the point $\bf x$, as it is most likely to move from its initial position.

To illustrate this, in the schematic, we exagerate this deformation.

It is clear that the point $P$ in the body has now moved to a new position, that we denote with $\bf y$.

\newpage

section: Mathematical description of shape changes in solids
content:
{In this section, we present various mathematical formulas that are used to characterize shape changes in solids (and in fluids).

The formulas might look scary at first, but they are mostly just definitions.

The remaining chapter assume that the reader has a deep konwledge of vectors, tensors and index notation. }

{As you work through the various definitions, you should bear in mind that shape changes near a point can always be characterized by six numbers.

These could be could be the six independent components of the Lagrangian strain, Eulerian strain, the left or right stretch tensors, or your own favorite deformation measure.

Given the complete set of six numbers for any one deformation measure, you can always calculate the components of other strain measures.

The reason that so many different deformation measures exist is partly that different material models adopt different strain measures, and partly because each measure is useful for describing a particular type of shape change.}

subsection: The Displacement gradient and Deformation gradient tensors
content:
In the description of solids and their deformation, it is important to quantify how much the solids are deforming (changes in shape and length), but also how fast these quantities are changing with respect to the material points.

In other words, if the change in length occurs in a much shorter length scale, the effect of that deformation will be more pronounced that another deformation that happens in a much larger space.

This is a little bit like time derivatives, but with respect to spatial coordinates.

Thus, we need to define quantities that contain geometrical information.

To quantify the pace at which the deformation changes, we can define the displacement gradient.

The physical meaning correspond to how fast the displacement are changing in the solid with respect to the spatial coordinates.

{Formally, the gradient of a vector field u(x) is defined so that}

$$

\left\lbrack {\mathbf{u} \otimes \nabla} \right\rbrack \cdot \mathbf{n} =   \underset{\alpha\rightarrow\text{0}}{\text{lim}}\frac{\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x} + \alpha\mathbf{n}) - \mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x})}{\alpha},$$

{ but in practice the component formula $$

\partial u_{i}/\partial x_{j}$$

is more useful.}\\

Associated with the displacement gradient, we can define the deformation gradient tensor, which is an important quantity that will help us to describe the deformation and strains in solids (and fluids too).

{ The deformation gradient tensor is defined as  $$

\mathbf{F} = \mathbf{I} + \mathbf{u} \otimes \nabla,\,\,\,\,\text{or in Cartesian components }\,\, F_{ik} = \delta_{ik} + \frac{\partial\, u_{i}}{\partial\, x_{k}}$$

} {where I is the identity tensor, with components described by the Kronecker delta symbol:}

$$

{and $$

\nabla$$

represents the gradient operator. } {Note also that}

$$

\begin{matrix {\mathbf{y} \otimes \nabla = \left( {\mathbf{x} + \mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x})} \right) \otimes \nabla = \mathbf{F}} \\ {\text{or   }\frac{\partial y_{i}}{\partial x_{j}} = \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{j}}\left( {x_{i} + u_{i}} \right) = \delta_{ij} + \frac{\partial\, u_{i}}{\partial x_{j}} = F_{ij}} \end{matrix}$$

} \\

![](image019.png) \\

{The concepts of displacement gradient and deformation gradient are introduced to quantify the change in shape of infinitesimal line elements in a solid body.

To see this, imagine drawing a straight line on the undeformed configuration of a solid, as shown in the figure.

The line would be mapped to a smooth curve on the deformed configuration.

However, suppose we focus attention on a line segment dx, much shorter than the radius of curvature of this curve, as shown.

The segment would be straight in the undeformed configuration, and would also be (almost) straight in the deformed configuration.

Thus, no matter how complex a deformation we impose on a solid, infinitesimal line segments are merely stretched and rotated by a deformation.The infinitesimal line segments dx and dy are related by}

$$

d\mathbf{y} = \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{x}\,\,\,\,\,\text{or   }dy_{i} = F_{ik}dx_{k}$$

{Written out as a matrix equation, we have}

$$

{To derive this result, consider an infinitesimal line element dx in a deforming solid.

When the solid is deformed, this line element is stretched and rotated to a deformed line element dy.

If we know the displacement field in the solid, we can compute dy={[x+dx+u(x+dx){]}-{[}x+u(x){]}} from the position vectors of its two end points}

$$

dy_{i} = x_{i} + dx_{i} + u_{i}(x_{k} + dx_{k}) - (x_{i} + u_{i}(x_{k}))$$

{Expand $$

u_{i}(x_{k} + dx_{k})$$

as a Taylor series}

$$

u_{i}(x_{k} + dx_{k}) \approx u_{i}(x_{k}) + \frac{\partial\, u_{i}}{\partial\, x_{k}}dx_{k}$$

{so that}

{We identify the term in parentheses as the deformation gradient, so }

$$

dy_{i} = F_{ik}dx_{k}$$

Inverse of the deformation gradient

{The deformation gradient tensor maps infinitesimal fiber segments from the reference to the deformed configuration.

The inverse of the deformation gradient then maps segments from  the  deformed to the reference configuration.

The inverse of the deformation gradient $$

arises in many calculations.

It is defined through}

dx_{i} = F_{ik}^{- 1}dy_{k}$$

$$

F_{ij}^{- 1} = \frac{\partial x_{i}}{\partial y_{j}}$$

content:
{ The displacement and deformation gradient tensors are important quantities to describe the changes of length and shape of bodies.

However, we typically want to dimensionalize these changes respectively to the size of the body.

For instance, imagine that we have a large bridge, say a 1 km (1000 m) long, that suffers a maximum vertical deflection of 1m.

Obviously, the maximum displacement will be here about 1 m.

Now let us imagine another bridge, that under the influence of loads, deform also 1m, but its length is about 100 m.

Clearly, the maximum displacement will be the same ($\sim  1$ m), but the effect of this displacement will be more pronounced, since the length of the bridge is much smaller.

Thus, while important, the displacement field give us only partial information.

The deformation gradient takes care of this issue, and therefore will be used to define critical measures for strains, which quantify the relative changes of legnth and distortions.

Next, we will define strain tensors, that a priori seem to be arbitrary.

However, these quantities have important physical meaning.

It is important to note that these quantities have been developed through years of mathematical studies in geometry and deformation, and you as student are not expected to natural or intuitively develop these metrics. }

![](image025.png)

{The Lagrange strain tensor quantifies the changes in length of a material fiber, and angles between pairs of fibers in a deformable solid.

It is used in calculations where large shape changes are expected.

The Lagrange strain tensor is defined as}

$$

\mathbf{E} = \frac{1}{2}(\mathbf{F}^{T} \cdot \mathbf{F} - \mathbf{I})\,\,\,\,\,\,\text{or}\,\,\,\, E_{ij} = \frac{1}{2}(F_{ki}F_{kj} - \delta_{ij})$$

{ The components of Lagrange strain can also be expressed in terms of the displacement gradient as}

$$

E_{ij} = \frac{1}{2}\left( {\frac{\partial\, u_{i}}{\partial\, x_{j}} + \frac{\partial\, u_{j}}{\partial\, x_{i}} + \frac{\partial\, u_{k}}{\partial\, x_{j}}\frac{\partial\, u_{k}}{\partial\, x_{i}}} \right)$$

{To visualize the physical significance of E, suppose we mark out an imaginary tensile specimen with (very short) length $$

l_{0}$$

on our deforming solid, as shown in the picture.

The orientation of the specimen is arbitrary, and is specified by a unit vector m, with components $$

m_{i}$$

.  Upon deformation, the specimen increases in length to $$

l = l_{0} + \delta l$$

. Define the strain of the specimen as}

$$

\varepsilon_{L}(m_{i}) = \frac{l^{2} - l_{0}{}^{2}}{2l_{0}{}^{2}} = \frac{\delta l}{l_{0}} + \frac{\left( {\delta l} \right)^{2}}{2l_{0}^{2}}$$

\\

{Note that this definition of strain is similar to the definition $$

\varepsilon = \delta l/l_{0}$$

you are familiar with, but contains an additional term.

The additional term is negligible for small $$

\delta l$$

. Given the Lagrange strain components $$

E_{ij}$$

, the strain of the specimen may be computed from}

$$

\varepsilon_{L}(\mathbf{m}) = \mathbf{m} \cdot \mathbf{E} \cdot \mathbf{m}\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\text{or   }\varepsilon_{L}(m_{i}) = E_{ij}m_{i}m_{j}$$

{We proceed to derive this result.

Note that}

$$

dx_{i} = l_{0}m_{i}$$

{is an infinitesimal vector with length and orientation of our undeformed specimen.

From the preceding section, this vector is stretched and rotated to }

$$

dy_{k} = \left( {\delta_{kj} + \frac{\partial\, u_{k}}{\partial\, x_{j}}} \right)dx_{j} = \left( {\delta_{kj} + \frac{\partial\, u_{k}}{\partial\, x_{j}}} \right)l_{0}m_{j}$$

{The length of the deformed specimen is equal to the length of dy, so we see that}

$$

\boldsymbol{\varepsilon} = \begin{bmatrix} \varepsilon_{xx} & \gamma_{xy} \\ \gamma_{yx} & \varepsilon_{yy} \end{bmatrix}$$

{is illustrated in the figure.}

{ }

{To relate this to the infintesimal strain tensor, let $$

\left\{ \mathbf{e}_{1},\mathbf{e}_{2},\mathbf{e}_{3} \right\}$$

be a Cartesian basis, with $$

\mathbf{e}_{1}$$

parallel to x and $$

\mathbf{e}_{2}$$

parallel to y as shown.

Let $$

\varepsilon_{ij}$$

denote the components of the infinitesimal strain tensor in this basis.

Then}

$$

\begin{array}{l} {\varepsilon_{11} = \varepsilon_{xx}} \\ {\varepsilon_{22} = \varepsilon_{yy}} \\ {\varepsilon_{12} = \varepsilon_{21} = \gamma_{xy}/2 = \gamma_{yx}/2} \end{array}$$

{For a general strain tensor (which could be any of $$

\mathbf{E}$$

, $$

\mathbf{E}^{*}$$

, or $$

\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}$$

, among others), the diagonal strain components $$

\varepsilon_{11}, \varepsilon_{22}, \varepsilon_{33}$$

are known as `direct' strains, while the off diagonal terms $$

\varepsilon_{12} = \varepsilon_{21}\,\,\,\,\,\,\varepsilon_{13} = \varepsilon_{31}\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\varepsilon_{23} = \varepsilon_{32}$$

are known as `shear strains'}

{The shear strains are sometimes reported as `Engineering Shear Strains' which are related to the formal definition by a factor of 2 i.e.}

$$

\gamma_{12} = 2\varepsilon_{12}\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\gamma_{13} = 2\varepsilon_{13}\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\gamma_{23} = 2\varepsilon_{23}$$

{This factor of 2 is an endless source of confusion.

Whenever someone reports shear strain to you, be sure to check which definition they are using.

In particular, many commercial finite element codes output engineering shear strains.}

{The deviatioric strain is a measure of shear deformation (shear deformation involves no volume change).}

{The infinitesimal rotation tensor is defined as}

$$

\mathbf{w} = \frac{1}{2}\left( {\mathbf{u}\nabla - \left( {\mathbf{u}\nabla} \right)^{T}} \right)\,\,\,\,\,\,\text{or    }w_{ij} = \frac{1}{2}\left( {\frac{\partial u_{i}}{\partial x_{j}} - \frac{\partial u_{j}}{\partial x_{i}}} \right)$$

{Written out as a matrix, the components of $$

w_{ij}$$

are}

$$

w_{ij}\,\,\,\, \equiv \,\,\,\begin{bmatrix} 0 & {\frac{1}{2}\left( {\frac{\partial u_{1}}{\partial x_{2}} - \frac{\partial u_{2}}{\partial x_{1}}} \right)} & {\frac{1}{2}\left( {\frac{\partial u_{1}}{\partial x_{3}} - \frac{\partial u_{3}}{\partial x_{1}}} \right)} \\ {\frac{1}{2}\left( {\frac{\partial u_{2}}{\partial x_{1}} - \frac{\partial u_{1}}{\partial x_{2}}} \right)} & 0 & {\frac{1}{2}\left( {\frac{\partial u_{2}}{\partial x_{3}} - \frac{\partial u_{3}}{\partial x_{2}}} \right)} \\ {\frac{1}{2}\left( {\frac{\partial u_{3}}{\partial x_{1}} - \frac{\partial u_{1}}{\partial x_{3}}} \right)} & {\frac{1}{2}\left( {\frac{\partial u_{3}}{\partial x_{2}} - \frac{\partial u_{2}}{\partial x_{3}}} \right)} & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

{Observe that $$

w_{ij}$$

is skew symmetric: $$

w_{ij} = - w_{ji}$$

.  }

{A skew tensor represents a rotation through a small angle.

Specifically, the operation $$

dy_{i} = \left( {\delta_{ij} + w_{ij}} \right)dx_{j}$$

rotates the infinitesimal line element $$

dx_{j}$$

through a small angle $$

\theta = \sqrt{w_{ij}w_{ij}/2}$$

about an axis parallel to the unit vector $$

n_{i} = \in_{ijk}w_{kj}/(2\theta)$$

.  (A skew tensor also sometimes represents an angular velocity).  }

![](image031.png)

{To visualize the significance of  $$

w_{ij}$$

, consider the behavior of an imaginary, infinitesimal, tensile specimen embedded in a deforming solid.

The specimen is stretched, and then rotated through an angle $$

\phi$$

about some axis q.

If the displacement gradients are small, then $$

\phi < < 1$$

.}

{The rotation of the specimen depends on its original orientation, represented by the unit vector m.

One can show (although one would rather not do all the algebra) that $$

w_{ij}$$

represents the average rotation, over all possible orientations of m, of material fibers passing through a point. }

{As a final remark, we note that a general deformation can always be decomposed into an infinitesimal strain and rotation}

$$

\frac{\partial u_{i}}{\partial x_{j}} = \frac{1}{2}\left( {\frac{\partial u_{i}}{\partial x_{j}} + \frac{\partial u_{j}}{\partial x_{i}}} \right) + \frac{1}{2}\left( {\frac{\partial u_{i}}{\partial x_{j}} - \frac{\partial u_{j}}{\partial x_{i}}} \right) = \varepsilon_{ij} + w_{ij}$$

{Physically, this sum of $$

\varepsilon_{ij}$$

and $$

w_{ij}$$

Principal values and directions of the infinitesimal strain tensor
content:
![](image033.png)

{The three principal values $$

e_{i}$$

and directions $$

\mathbf{n}^{(i)}$$

of the infinitesimal strain tensor satisfy}

$$

\begin{matrix} {\mathbf{\varepsilon} \cdot \mathbf{n}^{(i)} = e_{i}\mathbf{n}^{(i)}\,\,\,\,} \\ {\text{or  }\varepsilon_{kl}n_{l}^{(i)} = e_{i}n_{l}^{(i)}} \end{matrix}$$

{Clearly, $$

e_{i}$$

and $$

\mathbf{n}^{(i)}$$

are the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of $$

\mathbf{\varepsilon}$$

.  There are three principal strains and three principal directions, which are always mutually perpendicular.  }

{ }

{Their significance can be visualized as follows.}

\begin{itemize} \item{Note that the decomposition $$

\frac{\partial u_{i}}{\partial x_{j}} = \varepsilon_{ij} + w_{ij}$$

can be visualized as a small strain, followed by a small rigid rotation, as shown in the picture.}

\item{The formula $$

\mathbf{\varepsilon \cdot \mathbf{n}^{(i)} = e_{i}\mathbf{n}^{(i)}$$

}indicates that a vector n is mapped to another, parallel vector by the strain.}

\item {Thus, if you draw a small cube with its faces perpendicular to $$

\mathbf{n}^{(i)}$$

on the undeformed solid, this cube will be stretched perpendicular to each face, with a fractional increase in length $$

e_{i} = \delta l_{i}/l_{0}$$

.  The faces remain perpendicular to $$

\mathbf{n}^{(i)}$$

after deformation.}

\item {Finally, w rotates the small cube through a small angle onto its configuration in the deformed solid.}

{The decompositions}

{ }and $$

{are known as the right and left polar decomposition of F. (The right and left refer to the positions of U and V).

They show that every homogeneous deformation can be decomposed into a stretch followed by a rigid rotation, or equivalently into a rigid rotation followed by a stretch.

The decomposition is discussed in more detail in the next section.}

In this case, the directions $$

{The polar decompositions $$

\mathbf{F} = \mathbf{R} \cdot \mathbf{U}$$

and $$

\mathbf{F} = \mathbf{V} \cdot \mathbf{R}$$

provide a way to define additional strain measures.

Let $$

\lambda_{i}$$

\mathbf{u}^{(i)}$$

and $$

\mathbf{v}^{(i)}$$

denote the normalized eigenvectors of U and V.

Then one could define strain tensors through}

$$

\begin{array}{l} {\text{Lagrangian Nominal strain:                 }{\sum\limits_{\text{i=1}}^{\text{3}}{(\lambda_{i} - 1)\mathbf{u}^{(i)} \otimes \mathbf{u}^{(i)}}}} \\ {\text{Lagrangian Logarithmic strain:            }{\sum\limits_{\text{i=1}}^{\text{3}}{\log(\lambda_{i})\mathbf{u}^{(i)} \otimes \mathbf{u}^{(i)}}}} \end{array}$$

{The correspoinding Eulerian strain measures are}

$$

\begin{array}{l} {\text{Eulerian Nominal strain:                 }{\sum\limits_{\text{i=1}}^{\text{3}}{(\lambda_{i} - 1)\mathbf{v}^{(i)} \otimes \mathbf{v}^{(i)}}}} \\ {\text{Eulerian Logarithmic strain:            }{\sum\limits_{\text{i=1}}^{\text{3}}{\log(\lambda_{i})\mathbf{v}^{(i)} \otimes \mathbf{v}^{(i)}}}} \end{array}$$

section: Time change of the deformation gradient
content:
Similar to the deformation gradient -which measures how fast the deformation changes in space- we can now define time change of displacement fields.

This is important to quantify work rates (how fast energies are changing with respect of time) and will be important in formulation of principle of virtual work (for finite element methods, and variational methods).

We can also use it to define other important thermodynamic quantities such as entropy, work among others.

As other metrics, we can define several quantities that have specific physical meaning.

These quantities are define and discussed below.

section: Time change of the deformation gradient
content:
{We now list several measures of the rate of deformation.

The velocity gradient is the basic measure of deformation rate, and is defined as}

$$

\mathbf{L} = \mathbf{v} \otimes \nabla_{\mathbf{y}} \equiv L_{ij} = \frac{\partial v_{i}}{\partial y_{j}}$$

{It quantifies the relative velocities of two material particles at positions y and y+dy in the deformed solid, in the sense that}

$$

dv_{i} = v_{i}(\mathbf{y} + d\mathbf{y}) - v_{i}(\mathbf{y}) = \frac{\partial v_{i}}{\partial y_{j}}dy_{j}$$

{The velocity gradient can be expressed in terms of the deformation gradient and its time derivative as}

$$

\dot{\mathbf{F}} $$

$$

\mathbf{v} \otimes \nabla_{\mathbf{y}} = \dot{\mathbf{F}} \cdot \mathbf{F}^{- 1},           \frac{\partial v_{i}}{\partial y_{j}} = \dot{F}_{ik}F_{kj}^{- 1}$$

{To see this, note that}

$$

dv_{i} = \frac{d}{dt}dy_{i} = \frac{d}{dt}\left( {F_{ij}dx_{j}} \right) = \dot{F}_{ij}dx_{j}$$

{and recall that $$

\left. dy_{j} = F_{ji}dx_{i}\Rightarrow dx_{j} = F_{jk}^{- 1}dy_{k} \right.$$

, so that}

$$

dv_{i} = \dot{F}_{ij}F_{jk}^{- 1}dy_{k}$$

content:
\frac{d}{dt}d\mathbf{y} = \frac{d}{dt}\left( {\mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{x}} \right) =  \dot{\mathbf{F}} \cdot d\mathbf{x} =  \dot{\mathbf{F}} \cdot \left( {\mathbf{F}^{- 1}d\mathbf{y}} \right) =  \dot{\mathbf{F}} \mathbf{F}^{- 1} \cdot d\mathbf{y} = \mathbf{L} \cdot d\mathbf{y} = (\mathbf{D} + \mathbf{W}) \cdot l\mathbf{n}$$

{Hence}

$$

(\mathbf{D} + \mathbf{W}) \cdot l\mathbf{n} = \frac{dl}{dt}\mathbf{n} + l\frac{d\mathbf{n}}{dt}$$

{Finally, take the dot product of both sides with n, note that since n is a unit vector $$

d\mathbf{n}/dt$$

must be perpendicular to n and therefore $$

\mathbf{n} \cdot d\mathbf{n}/dt = 0$$

.  Note also that $$

\mathbf{n} \cdot \mathbf{W} \cdot \mathbf{n} = 0$$

, since W is skew-symmetric.

It is easiest to show this using index notation: $$

n_{i}W_{ij}n_{j} = n_{i}(L_{ij} - L_{ji})n_{j}/2 = 0$$

.  Therefore}

section: Strain Equations of Compatibility for infinitesimal strains
content:
{It is sometimes necessary to invert the relations between strain and displacement $$

–$$

that is to say, given the strain field, to compute the displacements.

In this section, we outline how this is done, for the special case of infinitesimal deformations.}

{For infinitesimal motions the relation between strain and displacement is}

$$

\varepsilon_{ij} = \frac{1}{2}\left( {\frac{\partial u_{i}}{\partial x_{j}} + \frac{\partial u_{j}}{\partial x_{i}}} \right)$$

{Given the six strain componets $$

\varepsilon_{ij}$$

(six, since $$

\varepsilon_{ij} = \varepsilon_{ji}$$

) we wish to determine the three displacement components $$

u_{i}$$

. First, note that you can never completely recover the displacement field that gives rise to a particular strain field.

Any rigid motion produces no strain, so the displacements can only be completely determined if there is some additional information (besides the strain) that will tell you how much the solid has rotated and translated.

However, integrating the strain field can tell you the displacement field to within an arbitrary rigid motion.}

{Second, we need to be sure that the strain-displacement relations can be integrated at all.

The strain is a symmetric second order tensor field, but not all symmetric second order tensor fields can be strain fields.

The strain-displacement relations amount to a system of six scalar differential equations for the three displacement components u\textsubscript{i}}.

{To be integrable, the strains must satisfy the compatibility conditions, which may be expressed as }

$$

\in_{ipm} \in_{jqn}\frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{mn}}{\partial x_{p}\partial x_{q}} = 0$$

{Or, equivalently} $$

section: Strain Equations of Compatibility for infinitesimal strains
content:
\frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{ij}}{\partial x_{k}\partial x_{l}} + \frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{kl}}{\partial x_{i}\partial x_{j}} - \frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{il}}{\partial x_{j}\partial x_{k}} - \frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{jk}}{\partial x_{i}\partial x_{l}} = 0$$

{Or, once more equivalently}

$$

\begin{array}{l} {\frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{11}}{\partial x_{2}^{2}} + \frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{22}}{\partial x_{1}^{2}} - 2\frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{12}}{\partial x_{1}\partial x_{2}} = 0} \\ {\frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{11}}{\partial x_{3}^{2}} + \frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{33}}{\partial x_{1}^{2}} - 2\frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{13}}{\partial x_{1}\partial x_{3}} = 0} \\ {\frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{22}}{\partial x_{3}^{2}} + \frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{33}}{\partial x_{2}^{2}} - 2\frac{\partial^{2}\varepsilon_{23}}{\partial x_{2}\partial x_{3}} = 0} \end{array}$$

{      }$$
